instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00045: What is 820-00045? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.U7100: What is U7100? U7100 refers to the ISL6259 or ISL9239 charging IC on Macbooks from 2013 to the present.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00045</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 12" Retina <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> is 20v
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> is 20v, and I've narrowed it down to the <CHIP>U7100</CHIP> chip because that is where it gets created, but the schematic is very confusing. It's getting power because it's letting power through, but I can't tell if its a buck converter afterward or the chip itself. The schematic is very confusing PAGE 43 which I'll include but I don't know where to check now.

There has been no history of drop damage or water. But when opened by my colleague he ripped the cables on the machine I replaced all of the cables and the original problem was that the keyboard wasn't working now trackpad doesn't work either.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00045</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 12" Retina <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> is 20v
threads.message: Likely have 20 volts because <TRANSISTOR>Q7110</TRANSISTOR> is shorted. Replace it <TRANSISTOR>Q7120</TRANSISTOR> <TRANSISTOR>Q7155</TRANSISTOR> and <CHIP>U7100</CHIP> all at once and see what happens

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00045</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 12" Retina <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> is 20v
threads.message:
Both <TRANSISTOR>Q7110</TRANSISTOR>/20 shorted on high-side MOSFET...
Confirm that posting ohm value between <RESISTOR>R7120</RESISTOR>/50.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00045</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 12" Retina <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> is 20v
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00045</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 12" Retina <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> is 20v
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00045</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 12" Retina <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> is 20v
threads.message:
And what voltages do you get on that board?
Any short on power rails?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00045</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 12" Retina <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> is 20v
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> = 4.6v
it only has 147 OHMS of resistance

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00045</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 12" Retina <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> is 20v
threads.message: Could that be a short from the chip

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00045</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 12" Retina <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> is 20v
threads.message:
Post diode mode reading on F7140; both ways, red and black to ground.
Do you really get 4.6V there?
If <TRANSISTOR>Q7110</TRANSISTOR>/20 are good (are you sure?), then bad <CHIP>U7100</CHIP>...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00045</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 12" Retina <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> is 20v
threads.message:
Red on ground = 203
black on ground = 212

Yes <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> = 4.6V
How do you check if <TRANSISTOR>Q7110</TRANSISTOR>/20 are good ?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00045</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 12" Retina <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> is 20v
threads.message:
Check them (diode mode) between D-S; all 4 MOSFETs (two pairs).
Only high-side ones are suspect there, but check all.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00045</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 12" Retina <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> is 20v
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00045</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 12" Retina <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> is 20v
threads.message:
To specify, <TRANSISTOR>Q7110</TRANSISTOR> and <TRANSISTOR>Q7120</TRANSISTOR>.
Did you check to ground, or D-S for each MOSFET?
I expected 4 readings...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00045</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 12" Retina <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> is 20v
threads.message:
Sorry that was to ground
I think this is right
<TRANSISTOR>Q7110</TRANSISTOR>: S1/D2 --> D1 = 0
<TRANSISTOR>Q7110</TRANSISTOR>: S1/D2 --> S2 = 472

<TRANSISTOR>Q7120</TRANSISTOR>: 1 --> 4: 636
<TRANSISTOR>Q7120</TRANSISTOR>: 1 --> 6: 634

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00045</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 12" Retina <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> is 20v
threads.message:
"<TRANSISTOR>Q7110</TRANSISTOR>: S1/D2 --> D1 = 0"
Exactly what I told you; hgh-side MOSFET of <TRANSISTOR>Q7110</TRANSISTOR> is shorted.
So change <TRANSISTOR>Q7110</TRANSISTOR>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00045</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 12" Retina <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> is 20v
threads.message:
Waiting on board from China.
I took <TRANSISTOR>Q7110</TRANSISTOR> off of the board and it didn't get rid of the short on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> still have around 140 Ohms

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00045</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 12" Retina <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> is 20v
threads.message:
"<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> still have around 140 Ohms"
Is that ohm scale, or diode mode with red probe to ground?
If diode mode, check if you get OL with black probe to ground.
If yes, change <TRANSISTOR>Q7110</TRANSISTOR> and test the board.
